body_full:
Some weeks ago I wrote about Bayesian A/B testing. In the comments, snoble asked for a visualization tool.

Well, I made one. (Thanks for my employer for hosting it.) It is completely self-contained. You can run it locally, If you download the page and the scripts. It is very slow on modern Firefoxes for some reason. Safari, Chrome and FF 3 are all reasonably fast.

I learned a great deal about the exercise.

The G-test is a whole lot easier to program (from scratch) and a whole lot faster. It also gives similar results as the Bayesian test even with small amounts of data (n ~ 5).

Numerical computation with JavaScript is bollocks. I may be a dynamic programming language kind of a guy, but even I have my limits. For example, I'd like to have at least a runtime warning when my function arity does not match. I'd also like to have some batteries included, such as the Gamma function.

If you are doing several computations per second and want some performance, use G-test. If you have to write the code from scratch on a desert island, use G-test. Otherwise prefer the Bayesian.

The bad news (and some good)

Note that using the probabilistic analysis alone does not seem enough to solve Evan Miller's warning about "How Not To Run An A/B Test". In addition to that article, here is an educational thread of blog posts:
  • Is Khan doing it wrong? Khan Academy seems to fall victim to Miller's problem.
  • Repeated tests: how bad can it be? Allen Downey analyzes and visualizes the issues raised by the previous post. A choice quote: "A/B testing with repeated tests is totally legitimate, if your long-run ambition is to be wrong 100% of the time."
  • Who knows what evil lurks in the hearts of men? The Bayesian doesn’t care gets somewhat further away from significance and A/B tests. However, it highlights some of the differences between frequentist and Bayesian thinking. Some of the results are counterintuitive at first. I guess that increases the probability of me being a crypto-Bayesian.

Evan Miller has a number of references. I went off and read Donald A. Berry's “Bayesian Statistics and the Efficiency and Ethics of Clinical Trials.” (It's googleable.) I don't know what to make of it. The paper is vague. I know many people would say that less math is better, but in this case I must disagree.

However, the gist of the paper seems to be that we should not think in terms of trials, but of processes. Instead of having an experiment, you'll have a continuous process in which you introduce new alternates all the time and remove old ones. This can be achieved nicely with Bayesian posterior probabilities: pick a number from each of the Beta distributions and display the alternate with the largest number. Sadly this can really wreck the quality of the code base, which makes the approach slightly less attractive.

Goals of medicine are different from the goals of companies. Berry wants to drive the amount of illness-related suffering down. Dang, that's not applicable. Websites don't feel pain.

What the website owners want is either a) understand their customers better or b) increase the number of what ever metric they are tracking with the A/B test. What we'd really need is a Bayesian process / sequential experiment designed with those goals in mind.
title: In which I convert to frequentism

Some weeks ago I wrote about Bayesian A/B testing. In the comments, snoble asked for a visualization tool.

I learned a great deal about the exercise.

Numerical computation with JavaScript is bollocks. I may be a dynamic programming language kind of a guy, but even I have my limits. For example, I'd like to have at least a runtime warning when my function arity does not match. I'd also like to have some batteries included, such as the Gamma function.

The bad news (and some good)

  • Who knows what evil lurks in the hearts of men? The Bayesian doesn’t care gets somewhat further away from significance and A/B tests. However, it highlights some of the differences between frequentist and Bayesian thinking. Some of the results are counterintuitive at first. I guess that increases the probability of me being a crypto-Bayesian.
